title: Tissue hydration
text:
Tissue hydration is the process of absorbing and retaining <a href="water">water</a> in <a href="Tissue%20%28biology%29">biological tissues</a>.
Plants.
Land plants maintain adequate tissue hydration by means of an outer waterproof layer. In soft or green tissues, this is usually a waxy <a href="plant%20cuticle">cuticle</a> over the outer <a href="epidermis%20%28botany%29">epidermis</a>. In older, <a href="wood">wood</a>y tissues, waterproofing chemicals are present in the secondary <a href="cell%20wall">cell wall</a> that limit or inhibit the flow of water. <a href="Vascular%20plant">Vascular plant</a>s also possess an internal <a href="vascular%20system">vascular system</a> that distributes fluids throughout the plant.
Some <a href="xerophyte">xerophyte</a>s, such as <a href="Cactus">cacti</a> and other desert plants, have mucilage in their tissues. This is a sticky substance that holds water within the plant, reducing the rate of dehydration. Some <a href="seed">seed</a>s and <a href="spore">spore</a>s remain dormant until adequate moisture is present, at which time the seed or spore begins to germinate.
Animals.
Animals maintain adequate tissue hydration by means of (1) an outer <a href="skin">skin</a>, <a href="Exoskeleton">shell</a>, or <a href="cuticle">cuticle</a>; (2) a fluid-filled <a href="coelom">coelom</a> cavity; and (3) a <a href="circulatory%20system">circulatory system</a>.
Hydration of fat free tissues, ratio of total body water to fat free body mass, is stable at 0.73 in mammals. 
In humans, a significant drop in tissue hydration can lead to the medical condition of <a href="dehydration">dehydration</a>. This may result from loss of water itself, loss of electrolytes, or a loss of blood plasma. Administration of <a href="hydrational%20fluid">hydrational fluid</a>s as part of sound <a href="Fluid%20replacement">dehydration management</a> is necessary to avoid severe complications, and in some cases, death. 
Some invertebrates are able to survive extreme <a href="desiccation">desiccation</a> of their tissues by entering a state of <a href="cryptobiosis">cryptobiosis</a>.
